citations.narrative:
Currently the dogs traveling and on exhibition are not microchipped and do not have an official USDA sequentially
numbered tag that is kept on the door of the animal's cage or run. As such these dogs have no formal identification. This
needs to be addressed and the dogs identified per this regulation while at home and on travel status.
Correct by: Sept 8, 2024

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The licensee has not submitted an itinerary to account for the travel status she is currently in for the summer months in
Buffalo, NY. Per this regulation and to facilitate inspections to assure the welfare of traveling animals, a written itinerary
must be submitted to the Deputy administrator at least two days prior to the start of travel that will last more than 24
hours. This needs to be completed for any and all future travel.
Correct by: Aug 5, 2024

Currently the dogs are kept in transportation crates, even though the exhibitor is no longer in travel status but at the show
location for the duration of the summer months. One dog (Kenny) who measured 29 inches long from head to base of tail,
would require a primary enclosure of 8.5 square feet. At the time of the inspection, he was in a crate that measured 3.8
square feet. The exhibitor must ensure the dogs are provided sufficient space that meet primary enclosure requirements
under this subpart.
Correct by: Sept 5, 2024
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the licensee.
This TRA was inspected in Buffalo, NY.
n

narrative:
2.50(c)(2)(ii) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
Currently the dogs traveling and on exhibition are not microchipped and do not have an official USDA sequentially 
numbered tag that is kept on the door of the animal's cage or run. As such these dogs have no formal identification. This 
needs to be addressed and the dogs identified per this regulation while at home and on travel status.  
Correct by: Sept 8, 2024 
2.126(c) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The licensee has not submitted an itinerary to account for the travel status she is currently in for the summer months in 
Buffalo, NY. Per this regulation and to facilitate inspections to assure the welfare of traveling animals, a written itinerary 
must be submitted to the Deputy administrator at least two days prior to the start of travel that will last more than 24 
hours. This needs to be completed for any and all future travel.  
Correct by: Aug 5, 2024 
3.6(c)(3) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Currently the dogs are kept in transportation crates, even though the exhibitor is no longer in travel status but at the show 
location for the duration of the summer months. One dog (Kenny) who measured 29 inches long from head to base of tail, 
would require a primary enclosure of 8.5 square feet. At the time of the inspection, he was in a crate that measured 3.8 
square feet. The exhibitor must ensure the dogs are provided sufficient space that meet primary enclosure requirements 
under this subpart.  
Correct by: Sept 5, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the licensee. 
 
This TRA was inspected in Buffalo, NY.

n
